awd_titl_txt: Triple-star dynamics and the internal structure of low-mass stars
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study the stars in triple-star systems, which have three stars orbiting a common center of mass. These systems have orbits which cause the stars to eclipse, or move in front of, eachother as seen during observation. The stars' movements will be used to determine their fundamental properties. The project takes advantage of the fact that the stars in a triple-star system are at the same distance from us, which makes it possible to determine their relative sizes. Follow-up spectroscopy of the stars' radial velocities and detailed modeling is used to determine absolute radii. Triple-star systems have very complicated motion, which changes their apparent brightness over time. The team will model these data to determine the internal mass distributions. They will train graduate students working on Master's degrees and undergraduate students working on senior thesis projects. The investigators will also incorporate research results into their college courses and public lectures. 

The work will be completed by examining, for the first time, the apsidal motion of three-body eclipsing binaries for stars less massive than the Sun. The rate of apsidal precession is related to the mass distribution inside the stars, which the team will model. They will use archival NASA Kepler mission lightcurves (photometric time series) and photo-dynamical computer models to measure the apsidal motion constants, which are directly related to the distribution and concentration of mass inside a star. The constants will be determined by modeling the changes in orbital period of the stars. They will use spectroscopy obtained at multiple ground-based telescopes to measure the radial velocities and determine the standard stellar photospheric characteristics, such as effective temperature, metallicity, surface gravity and rotational velocity. They will make publicly available the datasets and tools they developed to model multiple overlapping eclipse events for the astronomical community, as well as the eclipse times, and radial velocity measurements.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Using an unusual triple-star system called KOI-126, we have, for the first time, been able to measure the "internal structure constant" of stars smaller than the Sun. This tells us how concentrated the mass inside the stars are: Is the mass mostly condensed at the center, or is it more uniformly spread out? This is important because the central concentration heavily influences the way the star burns its fuel, and our current theoretical understanding of how small stars work is inadequate. This is despite the fact that small stars are by far the most numerous in the galaxy, and they tend to host planets that have characteristics similar to the Earth. Thus small stars are prime targets for the next generation telescopes that will attempt to measure their atmospheric composition, and perhaps be able to tell if there are any gases that might hint there is life on the planet. Although our measurement of the internal structure constant (also called the "apsidal motion constant") is not as precise as we wanted, it is good enough to tell us that it disagrees with the theoretical prediction. This should help lead us to a better understanding of these kinds of stars. As a necessary by-product of our investigation, we have made among the most accurate radius and mass estimates for any star: we have measured these to better than 1% for all three stars in the KOI-126 system.

During the course of our work, we needed to devise new techniques to be able to more accurately measure eclipses of stars and planets, and these techniques have been published and made available to the public. We used these methods to help discover three new planets of a rare and special kind: planets that orbit around two stars, not just one. We also were able to combine new data that we obtained with archival data to re-analyze a pair of stars that were predicted to spiral together, merge, and undergo a huge explosion in 2022. Our research revealed that there was an error in the data used in the previous analysis and, sadly, the two stars will not merge in our lifetimes. While disappointing, our result will prevent many people, both professional and astronomy enthusiasts, from wasting time, money, and precious resources monitoring a star that won't explode.

While doing our research, we have made it a priority to share our discoveries with the general public via press releases and interviews with the media so that they can share in the excitement and be inspired by science. And finally, we are delighted to say that this project involved three graduate students who have been lead authors on four separate refereed publications and two Master of Science thesis dissertations. We are proud to help train the next generation of scientists.
